case_name: Chinna Gowda and Rame Gowda v. State of Mysore

facts.text: Murder of an entire family consisting of eight persons occurred on the night intervening 12th and 13th February 1958 in Handigodu hamlet of village Viavalli.

anchor.surface_text: the murder of an entire family consisting of eight persons on the night intervening the 12th and 13th February, 1958, in Handigodu hamlet of the village Viavalli.

facts.text: Appellant China Gowda was tried along with six other persons for the murders.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-The appellant, China Gowda, was tried along with six other persons for company

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted all seven accused under section 302 IPC and sentenced each to death.

anchor.surface_text: . The learned Sessions Judge convicted every one of them under s. 302, Indian Penal Code, and sentenced each of them to death.

facts.text: High Court acquitted accused No. 2 Shivappa Naika and accused No. 7 Gunde Gowda.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the accused No. 2, Sbivappa Naika and accused No. 7, Gunde Gowda were acquitted.

facts.text: High Court confirmed conviction and death sentences of Chinna Gowda and Rame Gowda.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, confirmed the conv- viction and sentences only of the appellant Chinna Gowda and of Rame Gowda, appellant in Criminal Appeals Nos. 172 and 173 of 1961

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave under Article 136 to Chinna Gowda and Rame Gowda.

anchor.surface_text: and while affirming the conviction of the other three accused commuted the death sentences passed against them to imprisonment for life. The. appellants in the two appeals were granted special leave

facts.text: Mariappa Gowda took residence in Handigodu about eight or ten years prior to the murder.

anchor.surface_text: The facts as alleged by the prosecution are briefly these The deceased, Mariappa Gowda took up residence in Handigodu about eight or ten years prior to the murder.

facts.text: Mariappa Gowda became prosperous arousing envy of Chinna Gowda.

anchor.surface_text: He was an industrious and thrifty person and soon became very prosperous. This aroused the envy and jealousy of the appellant, Chinna Gowda.

facts.text: Numerous disputes over field boundaries, trespasses, water flow between Mariappa Gowda and Chinna Gowda.

anchor.surface_text: In the course of years, numerous disputes over the boundaries of fields, trespasses on fields, the flow of water and so on arose between the two of them.

facts.text: Relationship between Mariappa Gowda and appellants Chinna Gowda and Rame Gowda became strained prior to murders.

anchor.surface_text: For some time prior to the murders, the relationship between Mariappa Gowda deceased and the appellant as well as Rame Gowda, the appellant in the other appeal, became very strained.

facts.text: Rame Gowda lived with Mariappa Gowda and leased lands from him but they fell out.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that Rame Gowda was actually living with Mariappa Gowda for some time and Mariappa Gowda leased out some lands to him. Shortly thereafter, both of them fell out

facts.text: Dispute over rent receipt containing false recital of land surrender.

anchor.surface_text: Mariappa Gowda was, therefore, reluctant to issue receipts for rent paid by Rame Gowda, to him. This annoyed the latter. Eventually, however, on the intervention of Chandiah Hegde, P. W. 67, Mariappa Gowda passed a receipt in favour of Rame Gowda. To his surprise, Rame Gowda, however, found that the receipt contained false recitals

facts.text: Rame Gowda threatened Mariappa Gowda regarding eviction from leased lands.

anchor.surface_text: One day, he actually stopped the bullock cart of Mariappa and challenged him to try and evict him from the. leased lands.

facts.text: Mariappa Gowda's house situated about a furlong and a half from Chinna Gowda's house, no other house nearer.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that Mariappas house is situated about a furlong and a half of the house of Chinn Gowda and that no other house than Chinna Gowdas is nearer Mariappas house.

facts.text: Mariappa lived with wife Bellamma and six children, kept a dog and a loaded gun.

anchor.surface_text: Mariappa lived there with his wife Bellamma and six children. Since he was living in an isolated place, he bad kept a dog. He also used to keep a light burning outside his house. Further, he had a gun

facts.text: Dog died few days before the incident, cause unknown.

anchor.surface_text: Few days before the incident, the dog had died but the cause of the death of the dog is not known.

facts.text: PW 12 Narayan discovered the bodies between 6.30 and 7.00 a.m. on February 13, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Between 6.30 and 7.00 a.m. on the morning of February 13,1958, P.W. 12 Narayan of Handigodu who was employed as a labourer by Mariappa Gowda, went, as usual, to his masters house.

facts.text: Seven accused and PW 40 Venkappa Naika arrested after investigation.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, the first information was lodged with the police who commenced investigation. After investigation, the seven accused persons and P.W. 40, Venkappa Naika, who later turned an approver

facts.text: Venkappa Naika, Manjappa Gowda (A3), Manjappa Naika (A4) made confessions, later retracted.

anchor.surface_text: were arrested in connection with the murders. During the course of the investigation, P.W. 40, Venkappa Naika, accused No. 3 Manjappa Gowda, and accused No. 4, Manjappa Naika, made confessions.

facts.text: Venkappa Naika granted conditional pardon and turned approver.

anchor.surface_text: Venkappa Naika was tendered, a conditional pardon on his agreeing to give evidence on behalf of the prosecution.

facts.text: All accused except approver tried by Additional Sessions Judge, Chikmagalur.

anchor.surface_text: At the committal stage, all the three persons retracted their confessions. However, all the alleged participants in the crime, except Venkappa Naika, were sent up for trial and were tried by the Additional Sessions Judge, Chikmagalur.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted and sentenced all accused based mainly on approver evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge, relying mainly on the evidence of the approver, as corroborated by the retracted confessions of two of the accused persons, convicted sad sentenced all the accused persons. as already stated.

facts.text: Chinna Gowda arranged loan of Rs. 600 from PW 75 T. Shivaiah on Feb 13 1958 but did not go.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution further relied upon the fact that just prior to the date of the murders, Chinn Gowda, who was heavily pressed for money, had arranged to obtain a loan of Rs. 600/- for one T. Shivaiah alias T. Shivaswamy, P.W. 75, who had agreed to advance it to him on February 13, 1958.

facts.text: Appellants did not inquire about the incident or visit hospital unlike other villagers.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the courts below have relied upon the circumstance that the accused person, in particular the appellants in the two appeals before us, did not, like other innocent villagers, go to make enquiry about the incident

facts.text: Supreme Court holds approver evidence lacks corroboration in material particulars.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that his evidence cannot safely be regarded as the sole basis for resting the conviction of the two appellants before us.

under s. 302, Indian Penal Code, and sentenced each of them to death. In appeal, the accused No. 2, Sbivappa Naika and accused No. 7, Gunde Gowda were acquitted. The appeals of the remaining accused persons were dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-The appellant, China Gowda, was tried along with six other persons for companymitting the murder of an entire family companysisting of eight persons on the night intervening the 12th and 13th February, 1958, in Handigodu hamlet of the village Viavalli.
Venkappa Naika was tendered, a companyditional pardon on his agreeing to give evidence on behalf of the prosecution. At the companymittal stage, all the three persons retracted their companyfessions.

issues.text: whether conviction of the appellants could be sustained on the basis of the evidence of the approver and the retracted confessions of two of the accused persons

anchor.surface_text: The substantial material on which the case rests is thus the evidence of the approver and the retracted companyfessions of two of the accused persons. The question, therefore, is whether companyviction of the appellants companyld be sustained on the basis of this material.

issues.text: whether the evidence of P.W. 16, Dugamma and P.W. 59, Mariappa affords corroboration to the evidence of the approver on material particulars

anchor.surface_text: What is first to be companysidered is the evidence of P. W. 16, Duggamma and that of P. W. 59, Maryappa, sun of Ramae Gowda. We have already indicated that it does number afford companyroboration to the evidence of the approver.

issues.text: whether the confessions can safely be relied upon as affording corroboration to the evidence of the approver

anchor.surface_text: We have number been taken through the companyfessions of these two persons but we will assume that these two persons tell the same story as the approver but the question is whether the companyfessions can safely be relied upon as affording companyroboration to the evidence of the approver.

issues.text: whether the retracted confession of Manjappa Naika was validly recorded in compliance with s. 164 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The record does number show that when Manjappa Naika was produced before a magistrate on March 27, 1958, and remanded by him to the judicial custody he was given due warning by the magistrate and told that he should reflect whether he should make any companyfession at all.

arguments.claim: Section 133 Evidence Act allows conviction solely on approver evidence

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that s. 133 of the Evidence Act does not debar the court from basing the conviction of an accused person on the evidence of the approver alone

arguments.court_reasoning: True as matter of law but prudence requires corroboration

arguments.claim: Prudence requires corroboration of approver evidence in material particulars

anchor.surface_text: but as has been observed in a large number of cases, including the decision of the Privy Council in Bhuboni Sahu v. The King the Courts, as a matter of prudence, always require that the evidence of the approver should be corroborated in material particulars.

arguments.claim: Section 114(b) Evidence Act presumes accomplice unworthy unless corroborated in material particulars

anchor.surface_text: This rule has been founded on s. 114 b of the Evidence Act which enables the Court to presume that an accomplice is not worthy of credit unless he is corroborated in material particulars,

arguments.claim: Retracted confessions of co-accused usable under s30 Evidence Act but weak evidence

anchor.surface_text: their confessions can be used against the appellants under s. 30 of the Evidence Act. But a confession cannot be regarded as a piece of satisfactory evidence because it is not made in the presence of the person or persons whom it incriminates

arguments.claim: Confessions not independent as accused produced together before magistrate

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the record of these appeals that the confessions of the approver and Manjappa Gowda were recorded on the same day... they were actually brought together to the magistrates court. There is nothing to show that they were kept separate.

arguments.claim: Manjappa Naika confession invalid due to non-compliance with s164 CrPC requirements

anchor.surface_text: The record does not show that when Manjappa Naika was produced before a magistrate on March 27, 1958, and remanded by him to the judicial custody he was given due warning by the magistrate and told that he should reflect whether he should make any confession at all.

arguments.court_reasoning: Mind not free from influence; no adequate warning or time as per Sarwan Singh

arguments.claim: Evidence of PW59 Mariappa contradicts approver on material points

anchor.surface_text: Instead of affording any corroboration to the evidence of the approver, the evidence of this witness contradicts the approver on several points.

arguments.claim: Approver evidence alone insufficient due to bad character, retracted confession, illicit liquor business

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that his evidence cannot safely be regarded as the sole basis for resting the conviction of the two appellants before us.

arguments.claim: Lower courts did not regard approver evidence alone sufficient

anchor.surface_text: Indeed neither the Sessions Judge nor the learned Judges of the High Court regarded his evidence as being sufficient to justify conviction of the various accused persons.

holdings.text: The evidence of P.W. 16, Duggamma and that of P.W. 59, Mariayappa does not afford corroboration to the evidence of the approver on material particulars and in fact contradicts the evidence of the approver on some important points.

anchor.surface_text: What is first to be companysidered is the evidence of P. W. 16, Duggamma and that of P. W. 59, Maryappa, sun of Ramae Gowda. We have already indicated that it does number afford companyroboration to the evidence of the approver.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed analysis shows contradictions on key facts like timing, presence, and movements; partial corroboration insignificant.

holdings.text: Section 133 of the Evidence Act does not debar conviction on approver evidence alone, but courts as a matter of prudence require corroboration in material particulars.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that s, 133 of the Evidence Act does number debar the companyrt from basing the companyviction of an accused person on the evidence of the approver alone but as has been observed in a large number of cases, including the decision of the Privy Council in Bhuboni Sahu v. The King  1  the Courts, as a matter of prudence, always require that the evidence of the approver should be companyroborated in material particulars.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation combined with precedent (Bhuboni Sahu) and s.114(b); heightened need due to approver's bad character and retraction.

holdings.text: Section 114 illustration (b) of the Evidence Act enables presumption that accomplice is not worthy of credit unless corroborated in material particulars.

anchor.surface_text: This rule has been founded on s. 114 b  of the Evidence Act which enables the Court to presume that an accomplice is number worthy of credit unless he is companyroborated in material particulars, The need for such companyroboration would be all the more greater where,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory presumption to approver as accomplice.

holdings.text: Retracted confessions of co-accused under s.30 Evidence Act can be considered but are weak evidence, insufficient as corroboration without independence and testing by cross-examination.

anchor.surface_text: their companyfessions can be used against the appellants under s. 30 of the Evidence Act. But a companyfession cannot be regarded as a piece of satisfactory evidence because it is number made in the presence of the person or persons whom it incriminates and companysequently cannot be tested by cross-examination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory permission exists but inherent weaknesses per precedent (Bhuboni Sahu, Kashmira Singh); not proof alone.

holdings.text: Confessions of approver and Manjappa Gowda not independent as recorded same day after joint police custody without separation.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the record of these appeals that the companyfessions of the approver and Manjappa Gowda were recorded on the same day... they were actually brought together to the magistrates court. There is nothing to show that they were kept separate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record shows joint production post-police custody, opportunity for concert per Privy Council in Bhuboni Sahu.

holdings.text: Retracted confession of Manjappa Naika invalidly recorded under s.164 CrPC due to lack of warning, time for reflection, and assurance of free mind from police influence.

anchor.surface_text: The record does number show that when Manjappa Naika was produced before a magistrate on March 27, 1958, and remanded by him to the judicial custody he was given due warning by the magistrate and told that he should reflect whether he should make any companyfession at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-compliance with safeguards in Sarwan Singh v. State of Punjab: no explicit warning on reflection, use against him, despite remand.

holdings.text: Failure of Chinna Gowda to obtain loan on Feb 13, 1958 does not corroborate participation in murders.

anchor.surface_text: That leaves for companysideration only one circumstance on which the High Court has relied and that is the failure of the appellant, Chinna Gowda, number to go to the house of T. Shiviah alias T. Shivaswamy, P. W. 75, for receiving a loan on February 13, 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multiple possible reasons; even if linked to money from crime, does not prove participation.

holdings.text: Conviction of appellants cannot be sustained on uncorroborated approver evidence and unreliable retracted confessions.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial material on which the case rests is thus the evidence of the approver and the retracted companyfessions of two of the accused persons. The question, therefore, is whether companyviction of the appellants companyld be sustained on the basis of this material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No material corroboration found after examining all evidence; approver unreliable alone.

holdings.text: Approver's evidence cannot safely be the sole basis for conviction given bad character, retracted confession, and illicit activities.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that his evidence cannot safely be regarded as the sole basis for resting the conviction of the two appellants before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative infirmities; lower courts themselves required corroboration which is absent.

Precedent p3 (Kashmira Singh) supports c7 by discussing how confessions can lend assurance but with caution in accomplice context.
p3 warns of danger in using one accomplice confession to corroborate another, supporting h4 that retracted confessions are weak corroboration.

Precedent p5 in Sarwan Singh describes the magistrate's duties under s.164 CrPC to ensure free mind, warn, and allow reflection, directly establishing the requirements summarized in concept c6.
Precedent p5 supports holding h6 by providing the authoritative statement on s.164 CrPC requirements that h6 applies to find non-compliance.
Precedent p5 supports resolution of issue i4 by articulating the standards for valid s.164 CrPC confession recording.
